newsitem.title: USA: FBI agent says Gulf Cartel built on bribes, murder.
newsitem.headline: FBI agent says Gulf Cartel built on bribes, murder.

text.p: Reputed drug kingpin Juan Garcia Abrego relied on bribery and murder to eliminate competitors and build a massive Mexican drug organisation, a former FBI agent testified on Wednesday.

Retired FBI agent Claudio de la O said payoffs to government officials in Mexico helped Garcia Abrego avoid prosecution as he built a cartel that shipped billions of dollars in cocaine across the U.S.-Mexico border.

De la O told jurors a close friend of Garcia Abrego had said the reputed kingpin was aware of pressure on the mayor of Matamoros and the governor of the region "to intercede, to do something about Garcia Abrego," who was then operating his drug smuggling operation out of Matamoros.
"Yes, but with money they fix it," De la O said he was told in a secretly recorded conversation with a now deceased Brownsville, Texas, opthamologist and Garcia Abrego confidant.

Garcia Abrego has pleaded not guilty to 22 counts of drug trafficking and money laundering in a 28-count indictment against him and several alleged members of his so-called Gulf Cartel. If convicted, he faces up to life in prison and forefeiture of millions of dollars in drug proceeds.

After once working as a labourer in a Nabisco cookie plant in Mexico, Garcia Abrego allegedly went on to build an organisation that smuggled tons of cocaine and marijuana into the United States over the past 15 years.

Prosecutors allege his organisation was the shipping arm of Colombia's Cali cartel, taking a 50 percent cut of cocaine it shipped into the United States and laundering millions in drug proceeds to fund the operation.

By bribing police and government officials and providing information on activities of rival cartels, Garcia Abrego built a massive international drug smuggling ring, Assistant U.S. Attorney Melissa Annis said in opening arguments.

In 1986, De la O opened the U.S. investigation into Garcia Abrego and his cartel. Posing as a corrupt agent, he accepted three bribes totalling $170,000 from Garcia Abrego lieutenants in exchange for information he provided -- all of it false, he said -- on the progress of drug investigations.

After receiving an initial $100,000 payoff, De la O said, Garcia Abrego in handwritten notes and recorded telephone conversations began providing him with details of the activities of rival drug smugglers. "He's trying to vindicate himself, that he's being blamed for some of the violence, trafficking in the region," De la O said of Garcia Abrego's reasons for providing information on the rival cartels.

He said intermediaries from the Gulf Cartel sent by Garcia Abrego to meet with him talked of the murders of two rival traffickers and the mysterious death of a pilot who had been ferrying cocaine into the United States for another cartel.
